message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented suggest that the patient has viral conjunctivitis, which is self-limited and requires only supportive therapy such as warm compresses and artificial tears. Topical prednisolone acetate is not recommended as it may exacerbate viral replication, and both natamycin and erythromycin are used for fungal and bacterial infections, respectively, which are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of viral conjunctivitis, which is self-limiting and often resolves on its own in 1-2 weeks without treatment. Supportive therapy is the most appropriate next step in management, which includes cold compresses and artificial tears to relieve symptoms. Topical prednisolone acetate is indicated for severe inflammation, but since corneal sensation is normal, it is not necessary at this time. Topical natamycin is used for fungal keratitis, which is not supported by the patient’s symptoms. Topical erythromycin is used for bacterial conjunctivitis, but there is no evidence of a bacterial infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a viral conjunctivitis, and the patient has asthma, which can worsen with the use of steroids. Supportive therapy with cool compresses, artificial tears, and hygiene measures should be the first step in management. All other options are not recommended or contraindicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of acute conjunctivitis and her medical history reveals a diagnosis of asthma. Conjunctivitis can be a side effect of montelukast, which the patient is currently taking. Therefore, supportive therapy is the most appropriate management option at this time. Prednisolone acetate can exacerbate viral and bacterial infections, natamycin is used to treat fungal infections, and erythromycin is used to treat bacterial infections, but there is no indication of a specific causative organism in this case. Supportive therapy may include artificial tears, cool compresses, and proper hygiene to reduce the risk of spreading the infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest viral conjunctivitis, which should be managed with supportive therapy (e.g. cool compresses and artificial tears) as it is self-limiting. Topical corticosteroids can worsen the condition and should be avoided unless there is a specific indication. Topical antifungal and antibiotic agents are not indicated for viral conjunctivitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and exam findings suggest a viral conjunctivitis, which is self-limited and typically resolves within 7-14 days without treatment. Supportive therapy with cool compresses and artificial tears is the most appropriate management. Topical corticosteroids can worsen viral infections and are not recommended. Topical natamycin and erythromycin are used to treat fungal and bacterial conjunctivitis, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest viral conjunctivitis and the presence of preauricular lymphadenopathy supports this diagnosis. Supportive therapy with cold compresses and artificial tears is the most appropriate next step in management. Topical prednisolone acetate should be avoided as it can exacerbate the infection. Topical natamycin is used for fungal infections and topical erythromycin is used for bacterial infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has viral conjunctivitis, which is self-limiting and usually requires only supportive therapy such as artificial tears and cool compresses. Topical prednisolone acetate is not recommended due to the risk of worsening the infection. Topical natamycin is used to treat fungal keratitis, and topical erythromycin is used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs described in the patient are consistent with viral conjunctivitis. Treatment is typically supportive, with lubricating eye drops and warm compresses. Topical antibiotics are not effective against viral infections, and topical corticosteroids can worsen the infection or cause corneal complications. Topical antivirals may be used in severe cases, but are not recommended in mild to moderate cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the patient is most likely suffering from viral conjunctivitis. Topical antibiotics like erythromycin are not effective against viral infections and could promote antibiotic resistance. Prednisolone is a steroid and is not recommended in viral conjunctivitis, as it may prolong the infection. Therefore, supportive therapy such as artificial tears and cold compresses is the appropriate next step in management.
